text: The ICE processing facility in the western suburb of Broadview has become the primary physical and symbolic battleground documented in public reporting.
The pre-dawn raid on a five-story apartment building near 75th Street and South Shore Drive constitutes the most significant documented residential enforcement action.

In Logan Square, federal agents in an SUV deployed a tear gas canister on a busy street near the Rico Fresh supermarket and Funston Elementary School, an incident captured on video and representing a significant use of force in a dense, public area.
In Humboldt Park, an alderwoman was arrested by ICE agents inside Humboldt Park Health hospital while inquiring about an individual injured during an immigration arrest.
Other reports from the area describe federal agents entering a house near Thomas Street and Harding Avenue.
In Hermosa, multiple agents in military gear were spotted at a Home Depot and Chase Bank off Armitage and Cicero Avenues, with reports of pepper balls being fired and several people detained.
ICE agents were documented detaining a street vendor near the intersection of South Pulaski Road and South Archer Avenue.
Similar arrests of a tamale vendor in the Back of the Yards neighborhood and a snack vendor at a BP gas station near 46th and Damen were also reported.
The cumulative effect of these actions was a noticeable decrease in street vendor activity along the bustling 26th Street commercial corridor in Little Village.
Additional arrests were documented at intersections such as 47th and Marshfield and near 51st and Kedzie.
These patrols were observed on Michigan Avenue, one of the city's busiest shopping and tourist streets, and along the Chicago Riverwalk.

The most specific example involves CPD setting up checkpoints at the Division Street entrance to the lakefront path, where officers conducted bag checks.
